headline.main: The State of the Prozac Nation

docs.abstract: Was the antidepressant a true step forward in medicine, or did it just open the flood gates to aggressive marketing and branding of drugs?
docs.snippet: Was the antidepressant a true step forward in medicine, or did it just open the flood gates to aggressive marketing and branding of drugs?

docs.lead_paragraph: A North Carolina drugmaker is providing its experimental antiviral drug to a Dallas patient being treated for Ebola, an emergency step authorized by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline.main: Experimental Drug Provided to Dallas Ebola Patient
headline.print_headline: Experimental Drug Provided to Dallas Ebola Patient

docs.snippet: A North Carolina drugmaker is providing its experimental antiviral drug to a Dallas patient being treated for Ebola, an emergency step authorized by the Food and Drug Administration.

docs.lead_paragraph: To uncover patterns that might steer care, doctors and scientists are dipping into the medical records of thousands of patients.

headline.main: Can Big Data Tell Us What Clinical Trials Don’t?

docs.abstract: Veronique Greenwood Eureka column points out doctors and scientists are increasingly dipping into aggregated medical records of thousands or even millions of patients to uncover patterns that might help steer care; observes turning to enormous troves of data is replacement for large, costly and time-consuming clinical trials that are rarely carried out for uncommon medical complications.
docs.snippet: To uncover patterns that might steer care, doctors and scientists are dipping into the medical records of thousands of patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirteen clinics across Texas were forced to stop performing abortions because they did not meet the standards of a hospital-style surgery center, as now mandated by law.

headline.main: Texas Women Forced to Reassess After New Ruling on Abortions
headline.print_headline: Texas Women Forced to Reassess After New Ruling on Abortions

docs.abstract: Staff and patients at 13 clinics across Texas that were forced to stop performing abortions under new law struggle to reassess how and where they can receive procedure; federal appeals court had ruled that all clinics in state must meet building and staffing standards of hospital-style surgery center.
docs.snippet: Thirteen clinics across Texas were forced to stop performing abortions because they did not meet the standards of a hospital-style surgery center, as now mandated by law.

byline.original: By LAURA TILLMAN and ERIK ECKHOLM

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization has issued guidance in West Africa on collecting convalescent blood or plasma for transfusion, but there are obstacles.

headline.main: A Plan to Use Survivors’ Blood for Ebola Treatment in Africa
headline.print_headline: Health Officials Plan Use of Ebola Survivors’ Blood as a Treatment

docs.abstract: World Health Organization issues guidance on how to collect blood of people sickened by Ebola virus but who have since recovered, in effort to access antibodies that might help others fight off infection; treatment is not considered foolproof and there are many logistical problems in carrying this out in West Africa.
docs.snippet: The World Health Organization has issued guidance in West Africa on collecting convalescent blood or plasma for transfusion, but there are obstacles.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an annual report, the Food and Drug Administration said the amount of medically important antibiotics sold for use in animals raised for meat grew by 16 percent from 2009 to 2012.

headline.main: Antibiotics in Livestock: F.D.A. Finds Use Is Rising
headline.print_headline: Antibiotics in Livestock: F.D.A. Finds Use Is Rising

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration, in annual report, says amount of medically important antibiotics sold for use in animals raised for meat grew by 16 percent from 2009 to 2012, a pattern it says is troubling.
docs.snippet: In an annual report, the Food and Drug Administration said the amount of medically important antibiotics sold for use in animals raised for meat grew by 16 percent from 2009 to 2012.

docs.lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma doctor who performs nearly half the state's abortions filed a lawsuit Thursday to block a law that would require clinics to have a physician with admitting privileges at a nearby hospital present when an abortion is performed.

headline.main: Oklahoma Abortion Provider Sues Over New Law
headline.print_headline: Oklahoma Abortion Provider Sues Over New Law

docs.snippet: An Oklahoma doctor who performs nearly half the state's abortions filed a lawsuit Thursday to block a law that would require clinics to have a physician with admitting privileges at a nearby hospital present when an abortion is performed.

docs.lead_paragraph: Why is it so hard to get pain relief in the developing world?
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by journalist Ronald Piana highlights fact that six million cancer patients around the world suffer because they do not have access to morphine, gold standard for cancer pain control; examines array of bureaucratic hurdles, cultural biases and chilling effect of international war on drugs that restrict access to the drug, particularly in developing world.
docs.snippet: Why is it so hard to get pain relief in the developing world?

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Global Access to Pain Relief Initiative
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: There are now twice as many wild horses in the West as federal land managers say the land can sustain, and the system for keeping them under control is on the verge of crisis.

headline.main: As Wild Horses Overrun the West, Ranchers Fear Land Will Be Gobbled Up
headline.print_headline: As Wild Horses Overrun the West, Ranchers Fear Land Will Be Gobbled Up

docs.abstract: There are now twice as many wild horses in the West as federal land managers say the land can sustain, and the system for keeping them under control is on the verge of crisis.
docs.snippet: There are now twice as many wild horses in the West as federal land managers say the land can sustain, and the system for keeping them under control is on the verge of crisis.
